bioghist.p: Amalie Emmy Noether (1882-1935) was a German-born, Jewish mathematician, described by Albert Einstein at the time of her death as "the most significant creative mathematical genius thus far produced since the higher education of women began." She was known for her important, and controversial, work in abstract algebra and number theory. Although she was a highly regarded scholar and teacher, Noether's academic career in Germany was hampered by sexism and racism. She fled to the United States in 1933 to escape a Nazi edict which prohibited her from teaching. She joined the faculty at Bryn Mawr College with assistance from the Emergency Committee to Aid Displaced German Scholars, but died two years after her arrival in the United States.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of documents related to Emmy Noether. Materials include: letters from Noether to R. Brauer in German (1927-1934); English translations of those letters; correspondence regarding Noether's appointment at Bryn Mawr; correspondence about a memorial service for Noether; bibliographies of Noether's collection of reprints; and books and reprints on Noether's contributions to mathematics.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
